sect1.title: Filling a gap
sect1.para: Any Java programmer will, at any given time, face the need to execute remote HTTP requests. Google will most likely point you to Apache HttpClient or some other cheesy implementation based on JDK's URLConnection.

While these clients are fine for your trivial example and maybe even for you simple client application that just need to perform a couple of requests every now and then, you'll quickly discover that they don't scale when the number of requests rises above the four digit figures.

hotpotato is not your traditional Java HTTP client. Its purpose is not to become yet-another-simple-HTTP-client but rather a performance-focused tool that is able to eat the gobs of requests you throw at it to perform... And ask for more.

It was initially thought as a "server-side" HTTP client, kind of like a proxy to remote HTTP services that could handle thousands of concurrent requests as fast as possible, consuming as little resources as possible.
